ProviderName:
The Late Show with David Letterman
- CLOSED
ReviewText: Which TripAdvisor doesn't seem to know. Anyway, you’re on Broadway, and the tickets are free. The first ~250 people sit downstairs, the last ~150+ sit upstairs (but with the better view of the ceiling). We got there 90 minutes before they started handing out tickets, and were ~200 in line. (More people show up on days when the weather is nice, so arriving earlier is necessary.) The show is everything you see on TV, with more live music, the chance to ask Stephen questions, to watch how the magic happens, and to see real, live stars. It takes patience and stamina to stand in line for hours, but it’s a rare treat.
ProviderLocation: Ed Sullivan Theater, 1697 Broadway, between 53rd and 54th Sts , New York City , NY

ProviderName:
The Late Show with David Letterman
- CLOSED
ReviewText: You fill out an online form and they may call you. If they call you they ask a question about the show, our question was "What instrument does Paul Shaffer play?" Answer being keyboard. You show up a few hours early and they have you stay at the bar next door till your group is called. It gets crowded, but not out of hand. When your group is called they take you to the theatre, go over a few rules, and the band does some warm up songs. Once the show starts its very interesting how it is all laid out. Obviously you can't see the on screen graphics, but its really cool to see what Dave does when he is not on camera. The biggest surprise is they allow the band to restart if they mess up and editing will cut a seamless show afterwards. Dave does a lot of interacting with the audience and it even continued during the show, which lead to some hilarious inside jokes that I am sure didn't translate as well on tv. Its an experience that leads me to want to see more late night talk shows. Total experience is about 4 hours (including time at bar).
ReviewTitle: Very cool experience. Wish we could do it again.
ProviderLocation: Ed Sullivan Theater, 1697 Broadway, between 53rd and 54th Sts , New York City , NY

ProviderName:
The Late Show with David Letterman
- CLOSED
ReviewText: Liked the show, band, staff and the beautiful Ed Sullivan Theater.I'm very sad to see the show end and the theater being dismantled. I love NYC and always got excited seeing the marquee at this location
ProviderLocation: Ed Sullivan Theater, 1697 Broadway, between 53rd and 54th Sts , New York City , NY

ProviderName:
The Late Show with David Letterman
- CLOSED
ReviewText: David Letterman - as good live as on TV. Funny, hilarious and really having a go at guests that take themselves too serious. We signed up for free tickets and were among the lucky ones. They told us we were on the 'top ten' list - which turned out to be on the top of the balcony with practically no view at all, except for the monitors. Anyway, just to have been there while David Letterman still was on, hase been a great experience. The staff end the show pitchers were incredibly professional.
ProviderLocation: Ed Sullivan Theater, 1697 Broadway, between 53rd and 54th Sts , New York City , NY

ProviderName:
The Late Show with David Letterman
- CLOSED
ReviewText: Dave's show is history by now. Very hard to believe. Years ago in spring 2009 we spent a wonderful week in NYC. By accident (not really) we found the Ed Sullivan theater and a pretty nice line of people waiting for tickets. We were happy to be picked out of the crowd and get a short interview if we know the show in Germany. Actually I don't expected that we would get a call but the next night we found ourselves in the astonishing small theater just a couple feets away from Dave. An amazing experience, he was so cool and professional every minute. Thank you Dave and enjoy your retirement - 2 more friends from Germany will miss you!
ProviderLocation: Ed Sullivan Theater, 1697 Broadway, between 53rd and 54th Sts , New York City , NY

ProviderName:
The Late Show with David Letterman
- CLOSED
ReviewText: Posting a review seems pointless now that Dave is retiring and going off the air the week after this was written, but maybe this is how CBS will handle tickets for Stephen Colbert as well, so here it goes anyway: First of all, I'm a lifelong Dave fan and I put in for tickets on the Late Show website several months in advance knowing he was retiring, never dreaming they would actually contact me. Well, on Mon., May 11, 2015 the call came for tickets for the NEXT NIGHT'S show. I'm in Kansas City and would have to drop everything and fly out there on short notice, but this is a bucket list thing, so I accepted the offer! However, in order to claim the tickets, you had to answer an easy Late Show trivia question. In this case, it was "What instrument does Paul Shaffer play on the show?" The nice thing is that they took down the names of myself and my friend, who I conned into also dropping everything and going, so the tickets were now guaranteed, as long as we showed up between 3:00-4:00 PM the day of the taping and we had photo ID. There wasn't any threat of flying all the way out there and not having tickets. So, now I've got tickets, but being in Kansas City, I had to figure out how to get there. Having never been to New York, we sprang for the earliest flight there and the latest flight home to maximize our time in NYC. So, we flew into LaGuardia and took the E train to the Ed Sullivan Theater, got in line at 3:00 PM, where we were led into the theater to get our tickets. Showed the photo ID and we got our tickets. They normally tape at 4:30, but this day Bill Clinton was one of the guests and they moved the taping back an hour to accommodate schedules. So, we were told to leave the theater and come back at 4:50 to get into another line to actually get in for the show. So, Times Square is actually about 10 blocks away, so it was a no-brainer to hang out there, grab a bite and a drink and just people watch while we waited. We went back and got some Late Show gear at the Hello Deli, around the corner from the theater, and got a photo taken with the owner, Rupert Jee. We got in the 4:50 PM line and were actually led into the theater. I read on previous Trip Advisor reviews that they make you check bags and cell phones, but they didn't do either to us. They just ask that phones are turned completely off (so, no photos allowed inside the theater), and they do have numerous pages running around before, during and after the taping in the audience looking to tell people to put their phones away, so unfortunately, I couldn't get away with taking photos inside the theater. There doesn't seem to be a method on how they seat you--some people in our line went down to the floor, some went up into the balcony. We happened to sit in the balcony, which bummed us out at first, but we heard the view is much better up there because all the cameras aren't in the way like they would be downstairs. The taping itself was great...before the show started, announcer Alan Kalter warmed up the crowd, the CBS Orchestra played a couple of numbers, Paul Shaffer was brought out to a huge ovation and then Dave himself came out to take questions from the audience for about 10 minutes. Then, at about 5:45 PM, the show started, and it's just like what you see on TV, except now you get to see what happens during the commercial breaks. Most breaks Dave got up and went backstage only to return a few seconds before coming back on the air to host the next segment. The band plays throughout the entire commercial and they really did sound great. The guests were Bill Clinton and Adam Sandler for Dave's 7th to last show. The Ed Sullivan Theater really looks much larger on TV...even though we sat in the balcony, you felt like you were only 100 feet away from Dave and the stage. The taping was over at about 6:45 PM. With the show taping an hour later than we originally were planning for, we had to hustle and get a cab (instead of a train) to get to Newark to fly out at 8:30 PM. We made it home to Kansas City by 10:30 PM, so it was a 17-hour crazy adventure that cost an arm and a leg, but to be able to now say that I got to see Dave in person on his second-to-last week, that's pretty priceless!
ProviderLocation: Ed Sullivan Theater, 1697 Broadway, between 53rd and 54th Sts , New York City , NY

ProviderName:
The Late Show with David Letterman
- CLOSED
ReviewText: I love that show and when I was in front of Ed Sullivan theatre it was great. Unfortunately that day Letterman wasn't there but I met Rupert and bought staff at Hello Deli. he is a nice guy. hope to come back to NY
ProviderLocation: Ed Sullivan Theater, 1697 Broadway, between 53rd and 54th Sts , New York City , NY

ProviderName:
The Late Show with David Letterman
- CLOSED
ReviewText: For me and my generation... the King of Late Night is David Letterman. For others the King may be Johnny Carson, Ed Sullivan or Dave's replacement Steve C. Seeing Dave in person on his show has been a "Bucket List" item for me, and since Dave will be retiring soon it was "now or never". The procedure for getting tickets is going online a month in advance and getting a phone call a week before the show. Answer a simple trivia question and show up early. When you show up, you will have to wait a while in line for the distribution of tickets. You get your ticket and come back about 90 minutes later. I suggest going to the Courtyard by Marriott on the next block North and wait in the lounge on the 4th floor. The restrooms there are nice and clean... no hassle. The show itself is an amazing experience and so much better than watching it between your feet in bed. The show featured John Mayer and Alec Baldwin as guests when I visited. I sat a couple rows back from Paul S. and the band. AWESOME!!!
ProviderLocation: Ed Sullivan Theater, 1697 Broadway, between 53rd and 54th Sts , New York City , NY

ProviderName:
The Late Show with David Letterman
- CLOSED
ReviewText: Let me give ya the Readers Digest version of our David Letterman experience while in NYC ... A couple weeks before traveling to NYC to finish out mortuary school I had applied online for tickets. A few days before arriving in town I received a call from The Late Show promotions department offering two tickets. Needless to say I was ecstatic. The problem I ran into was that my classes for the day our tickets were for, Tuesday, were not to let out until 3pm. The LS staff needed us there before 3. The theater was just a few blocks from my school. Needless to say the school said there would be no early dismissal. Regrettably I had to pass on the tickets. Here's where it gets good; when Tuesday rolled around, I of course, went to my classes. At 2:15 the instructor said unexpectedly, "Ok, that's it, see everyone tomorrow" I sat stunned. I quickly ran out of the building, caught a cab down to the Port Authority to meet up with my wife, caught another cab; and made a mad dash to the Ed Sullivan Theater. We were told that we could be placed on a "standby" list for tickets if any would be left for the evening's show. Long and the short of it; we waited around the corner with a group of people, all hoping to get it ... We GOT IN!! #36 & 37 of 39. Our seats were in the last row in the upper left of the balcony right above the sound board for the orchestra. Could not see Paul Shaffer, but we knew he was there. We had a "reasonable" view of the set and of course Dave. Billy Crystal and Connie Chen were Dave's guest. BOTTOM LINE: We got to see and experience Letterman in his final few weeks before his farewell. No regrets.
ProviderLocation: Ed Sullivan Theater, 1697 Broadway, between 53rd and 54th Sts , New York City , NY

ProviderName:
The Late Show with David Letterman
- CLOSED
ReviewText: I requested tickets online about a month in advance and never herd back so assumed there were none available. While in New York, a staff member from the show called, asked us a trivia question and then gave us tickets. We arrived the day of to pick them up and had to wait in line for about 45 minutes. We then left and came back at 3:30 as requested and waiting for about an hour in another line. The waiting was boring and there were no bathrooms, but once inside the theater, it is 100% worth it. The band was amazing, Dave was amazing and did take time to talk to the audience. Martin Short, Norah Jones, and Cher were on the show and we had the best time. I am so thankful we were able to see Dave before he retires. Amazing!
ProviderLocation: Ed Sullivan Theater, 1697 Broadway, between 53rd and 54th Sts , New York City , NY

ReviewText: Posting a review seems pointless now that Dave is retiring and going off the air the week after this was written, but maybe this is how CBS will handle tickets for Stephen Colbert as well, so here it goes anyway: First of all, I'm a lifelong Dave fan and I put in for tickets on the Late Show website several months in advance knowing he was retiring, never dreaming they would actually contact me. Well, on Mon., May 11, 2015 the call came for tickets for the NEXT NIGHT'S show. I'm in Kansas City and would have to drop everything and fly out there on short notice, but this is a bucket list thing, so I accepted the offer! However, in order to claim the tickets, you had to answer an easy Late Show trivia question. In this case, it was "What instrument does Paul Shaffer play on the show?" The nice thing is that they took down the names of myself and my friend, who I conned into also dropping everything and going, so the tickets were now guaranteed, as long as we showed up between 3:00-4:00 PM the day of the taping and we had photo ID. There wasn't any threat of flying all the way out there and not having tickets. So, now I've got tickets, but being in Kansas City, I had to figure out how to get there. Having never been to New York, we sprang for the earliest flight there and the latest flight home to maximize our time in NYC. So, we flew into LaGuardia and took the E train to the Ed Sullivan Theater, got in line at 3:00 PM, where we were led into the theater to get our tickets. Showed the photo ID and we got our tickets. They normally tape at 4:30, but this day Bill Clinton was one of the guests and they moved the taping back an hour to accommodate schedules. So, we were told to leave the theater and come back at 4:50 to get into another line to actually get in for the show. So, Times Square is actually about 10 blocks away, so it was a no-brainer to hang out there, grab a bite and a drink and just people watch while we waited. We went back and got some Late Show gear at the Hello Deli, around the corner from the theater, and got a photo taken with the owner, Rupert Jee. We got in the 4:50 PM line and were actually led into the theater. I read on previous Trip Advisor reviews that they make you check bags and cell phones, but they didn't do either to us. They just ask that phones are turned completely off (so, no photos allowed inside the theater), and they do have numerous pages running around before, during and after the taping in the audience looking to tell people to put their phones away, so unfortunately, I couldn't get away with taking photos inside the theater. There doesn't seem to be a method on how they seat you--some people in our line went down to the floor, some went up into the balcony. We happened to sit in the balcony, which bummed us out at first, but we heard the view is much better up there because all the cameras aren't in the way like they would be downstairs. The taping itself was great...before the show started, announcer Alan Kalter warmed up the crowd, the CBS Orchestra played a couple of numbers, Paul Shaffer was brought out to a huge ovation and then Dave himself came out to take questions from the audience for about 10 minutes. Then, at about 5:45 PM, the show started, and it's just like what you see on TV, except now you get to see what happens during the commercial breaks. Most breaks Dave got up and went backstage only to return a few seconds before coming back on the air to host the next segment. The band plays throughout the entire commercial and they really did sound great. The guests were Bill Clinton and Adam Sandler for Dave's 7th to last show. The Ed Sullivan Theater really looks much larger on TV...even though we sat in the balcony, you felt like you were only 100 feet away from Dave and the stage. The taping was over at about 6:45 PM. With the show taping an hour later than we originally were planning for, we had to hustle and get a cab (instead of a train) to get to Newark to fly out at 8:30 PM. We made it home to Kansas City by 10:30 PM, so it was a 17-hour crazy adventure that cost an arm and a leg, but to be able to now say that I got to see Dave in person on his second-to-last week, that's pretty priceless!
ProviderLocation: Ed Sullivan Theater, 1697 Broadway, between 53rd and 54th Sts , New York City , NY

ProviderName:
The Late Show with David Letterman
- CLOSED
ReviewText: For me and my generation... the King of Late Night is David Letterman. For others the King may be Johnny Carson, Ed Sullivan or Dave's replacement Steve C. Seeing Dave in person on his show has been a "Bucket List" item for me, and since Dave will be retiring soon it was "now or never". The procedure for getting tickets is going online a month in advance and getting a phone call a week before the show. Answer a simple trivia question and show up early. When you show up, you will have to wait a while in line for the distribution of tickets. You get your ticket and come back about 90 minutes later. I suggest going to the Courtyard by Marriott on the next block North and wait in the lounge on the 4th floor. The restrooms there are nice and clean... no hassle. The show itself is an amazing experience and so much better than watching it between your feet in bed. The show featured John Mayer and Alec Baldwin as guests when I visited. I sat a couple rows back from Paul S. and the band. AWESOME!!!
ProviderLocation: Ed Sullivan Theater, 1697 Broadway, between 53rd and 54th Sts , New York City , NY

ProviderName:
The Late Show with David Letterman
- CLOSED
ReviewText: Let me give ya the Readers Digest version of our David Letterman experience while in NYC ... A couple weeks before traveling to NYC to finish out mortuary school I had applied online for tickets. A few days before arriving in town I received a call from The Late Show promotions department offering two tickets. Needless to say I was ecstatic. The problem I ran into was that my classes for the day our tickets were for, Tuesday, were not to let out until 3pm. The LS staff needed us there before 3. The theater was just a few blocks from my school. Needless to say the school said there would be no early dismissal. Regrettably I had to pass on the tickets. Here's where it gets good; when Tuesday rolled around, I of course, went to my classes. At 2:15 the instructor said unexpectedly, "Ok, that's it, see everyone tomorrow" I sat stunned. I quickly ran out of the building, caught a cab down to the Port Authority to meet up with my wife, caught another cab; and made a mad dash to the Ed Sullivan Theater. We were told that we could be placed on a "standby" list for tickets if any would be left for the evening's show. Long and the short of it; we waited around the corner with a group of people, all hoping to get it ... We GOT IN!! #36 & 37 of 39. Our seats were in the last row in the upper left of the balcony right above the sound board for the orchestra. Could not see Paul Shaffer, but we knew he was there. We had a "reasonable" view of the set and of course Dave. Billy Crystal and Connie Chen were Dave's guest. BOTTOM LINE: We got to see and experience Letterman in his final few weeks before his farewell. No regrets.
ProviderLocation: Ed Sullivan Theater, 1697 Broadway, between 53rd and 54th Sts , New York City , NY

ProviderName:
The Late Show with David Letterman
- CLOSED
ReviewText: I requested tickets online about a month in advance and never herd back so assumed there were none available. While in New York, a staff member from the show called, asked us a trivia question and then gave us tickets. We arrived the day of to pick them up and had to wait in line for about 45 minutes. We then left and came back at 3:30 as requested and waiting for about an hour in another line. The waiting was boring and there were no bathrooms, but once inside the theater, it is 100% worth it. The band was amazing, Dave was amazing and did take time to talk to the audience. Martin Short, Norah Jones, and Cher were on the show and we had the best time. I am so thankful we were able to see Dave before he retires. Amazing!
ProviderLocation: Ed Sullivan Theater, 1697 Broadway, between 53rd and 54th Sts , New York City , NY

ReviewText: Watched the show in Grand Rapids, Michigan last week while attending ArtPrize. It is fun but nothing spectacular.
ProviderLocation: 208 West 41st Street , Nederlander Theatre , New York City , NY 10036

ReviewText: I thoroughly enjoyed this high-energy, wonderfully choreographed musical! Hubby .... not so much. The time frame was the late 1800's, so the production may seem to be a bit dated to some. But, for me, this was exactly what I expected and wanted. Great ensemble cast! Innovative stage production! You won't leave the theater singing any one song in particular, but the overall score was good. A wonderful evening's entertainment!
ProviderLocation: 208 West 41st Street , Nederlander Theatre , New York City , NY 10036

ReviewText: Great show for the whole family, but now it's closed. If there's a traveling version, be sure to see it.
ProviderLocation: 208 West 41st Street , Nederlander Theatre , New York City , NY 10036

ReviewText: Took my daughter to see to end her 15th birthday. We loved it. While visiting Manhattan it is a definite must do. The best way to end any stay.
ReviewTitle: Theater nite with b day girl
ProviderLocation: 208 West 41st Street , Nederlander Theatre , New York City , NY 10036

ReviewText: I am reviewing the touring production which I had the pleasure of seeing at the Smith Center in Las Vegas and the Pantages in Los Angeles. Great energy by the entire cast. Everyone is giving 100% and really seem to enjoy what they are doing. I enjoyed the tour more than the original Broadway Cast. Looking forward to catching it again in Boston this summer.
ProviderLocation: 208 West 41st Street , Nederlander Theatre , New York City , NY 10036

ReviewText: My 6 year-old son and I saw this musical just last night at Pantages Theater in Los Angeles. We both loved it! My son loves the movie, so I was taken back a little bit with a new character (Katherine) and a lack of Kid Blink - the actually leader of Newsboys Strike. Still he loved it, and I enjoyed it much more than the movie. The show was so energetic with great singing and acrobatic dance numbers. I also thought the dialog was really good - Katherine (played by Stephanie Styles) made this musical really Disney by being the usual Disney female lead - perky and independent like Anna and Rapunzel. Mr. Jacobi (played by Michael Gorman) was so funny. The dancers were just so amazingly great that it made me want to go back and see the show again!
ProviderLocation: 208 West 41st Street , Nederlander Theatre , New York City , NY 10036

ReviewText: Songs were plain and not outstanding; it was hard to understand the words and the plot was weak. The dancers were good but that is not enough to spend that type of money
ReviewTitle: Newsies at the Smith Center in Las Vegas
ProviderLocation: 208 West 41st Street , Nederlander Theatre , New York City , NY 10036

ReviewText: I took my son to Newsies last night. What a great fast paced energenic musical. The actors were a triple threat with great dancing, acting and singing. A great show.
ProviderLocation: 208 West 41st Street , Nederlander Theatre , New York City , NY 10036

ReviewText: I went into this play not knowing much about the story and was blown away by the performances. The singing was wonderful but the dancing really put it over the top. I would love to see it again.
ProviderLocation: 208 West 41st Street , Nederlander Theatre , New York City , NY 10036

ReviewText: This was a fantastic play! The dancing and staging were excellent! However, the signing was just okay. I enjoyed the storyline and wished they could have developed the "poor children's campaign" more. Nonetheless, I enjoyed it tremendously.
